The internationally revered techno superstars Underworld pay tribute to their art-school roots on their new compilation album, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œAthensÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½.

The first in a series, this rich musical mix is packed with rare grooves and cult gems from the outer limits of dance music, jazz-rock, fusion and progressive pop. This album shows the open-minded flipside of Underworld, the more eclectic and experimental foundations that lie beneath their shimmering electro soundscapes. The album is credited to Underworld vs The Misterons, a collective alter ego which includes the groupÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s core members Karl Hyde and Rick Smith, their regular studio and live collaborator Darren Price, plus creative mastermind Steven Hall. Ranging far and wide across musical genres and eras, this music will appeal equally to vinyl-loving connoisseurs and arty party hedonists. The grooves are still funky, but the vibes are warm and soulful, with more live instruments than sequencers or drum machines.

The overall mood is jazz and improvisation,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ Underworld explain. It doesnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t stop us loving machine music and house music and everything that goes with it, but the idea with this album was to highlight records we liked that we thought had great live playing on them.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½

United more by spirit than sound, the tracks on Athens offer a musical journey from inner space to the dancefloor, and back again. The musical agenda is limitless, the rhythms infectious, the mood hypnotic.

You do become stereotyped, so for us it is nice to get pieces like this out and show that we can recontextualise our sound. WeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ve never tried to make current, trendy techno records. WeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ve always tried to make something more adventurous and timeless than that.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½

Karl also delivers one of his signature stream-of-consciousness raps on the albumÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s climactic cut, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œBeebop Hurry,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ a collaboration with the legendary polymath producer Brian Eno conceived during sessions for EnoÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s Luminous Festival of experimental music, which was held at the Sydney Opera House in May and June 2009. This was a track from those sessions that we thought fitted the concept we had anyway. WeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ve got a very broad definition of jazz.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½

A younger version of Eno can also be heard elsewhere on the album, in the Roxy Music classic ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œ2HB,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ an achingly romantic torch song from the bandÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s eponymous 1972 debut album. The vibrant British art-rock scene of the early 1970s, often overlooked by pop historians, was one of the key inspirations behind the musical selection and creative input on Athens. Indeed, Soft MachineÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s intoxicating jazz-rock instrumental ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œPenny HitchÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ from 1973 was the original catalyst for the entire project and the cover artwork is a painting by Karl Hyde himself.

They are a band that people should listen to now because so much of what we now think of as techno appears in a lot of Soft Machine stuff. Their use of early synths was incredible.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½

Athens is an irresistible sonic collage of pop and art, old and new, cult heroes and left-field classics. Welcome to the warm, soulful, experimental roots of the worldÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s greatest techno conceptualists. Take a ride on UnderworldÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s flipside.
